title: Puritan Spotting
summary:
Key Ideas:
- The author defines a category he calls "Puritan", which involves characteristics such as being eccentric, over-educated, hyper-competent, contrarian, and taking morality seriously. 
- The author provides a humorous Puritan checklist as a way of ranking historical figures by Puritanism points.
- The author argues that the modern American stereotype of the impulsive, gun-crazy, fundamentalist hillbilly has eclipsed the stereotype of the virtue-obsessed nonconformist eccentric inventor philanthropist.

Key Learnings:
- The Puritan category is difficult to define in a concise way, but involves a range of characteristics related to morality and non-conformity.
- The Puritan checklist can be used to rank famous historical figures in terms of their Puritanism points, based on their life circumstances and achievements.
- The stereotype of the eccentric inventor philanthropist has largely disappeared and is not part of the US national identity.

Key Questions:
- What other categories exist that are similar to the one described as "Puritan"?
- How might the emphasis on the stereotype of the impulsive, gun-crazy, fundamentalist hillbilly affect national identity in the US?
- Are the categories used to rank historical figures by Puritanism points arbitrary or does the author use specific criteria?
